Award.AwardTitle: Frame-Based Kernel Analysis and Algorithms for Fast Recovery of Erasures and Multiplexing
Award.AbstractNarration:
Accurate transmission of messages is critical in many areas of application in our information-based society. But a message can be distorted in many ways, often arriving with erasures in parts of the message. In such cases, most frame-based methods to restore the message have been aimed at either fast reconstruction of the message (but allowing approximation errors) or perfect reconstruction (but usually with expensive computational cost). In this project the investigator targets problems related to both fast and accurate recovery of the lost data from either known or unknown locations in the message. This has direct applications in information technology, biotechnology, and communications, particularly in multiplexing where expensive channels are shared and the multiplexed data are used to enhance coding security. Students will be trained in the course of this project.

The principal investigator and his students work on three fundamental questions concerning the use of frames for fast and accurate recovery of signals with erasures: (i) Develop new approaches to the problem of recovering signals from the frame coefficients when there are erasures at either known or unknown locations. The investigation includes both theoretical analysis and new algorithms. The main objective is to characterize and identify the encoding frames that ensure fast and perfect recovery of the erasures for almost all input signals when erasures occur at possibly unknown locations. (ii) Develop theory and algorithms for optimal superframes and erasure recovery in channel-sharing applications. Multiplexing combines several messages into a single one, which must then be decoded -- that is, its separate component messages must be extracted. Multiplexing usually is done to share an expensive resource, such as a channel, or to enhance the security of the component messages. The investigator studies conditions on superframes that allow perfect recovery from erasures while maintaining information security among the receivers of the different component messages. (iii) Study spectrally optimal frames. The chief aim here is to characterize spectrally k-uniform or near k-uniform frames. Additionally, the investigator continues to work on problems related to the theory of frame dilations and its connections to the Similarity Problem.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In recent years frame theory has become one of the important tools introduced to help establishing new theories and developing new techniques to address application demands for fast and effective data processing. The main scope of this project is to conduct both theoretical analysis and numerical simulations in the areas where the theory of frames can be used for fast and perfect signal recovering with corrupted data sets. The new theory/discovery resulted from investigation directly targeted applications in signal/information processing, communications (multiplexing) and coding security. This project also provided excellent opportunities for both graduate and undergradaute trainings. 

With the support of this project the PI and his collaborators were able to achieve all the main objectives outlined in the project. The main outcomes resulted from this project include but not limited to: (a) Completely classified the frames that can be used to recover every input signals from its erasure-corrupted frame coefficients at unknown locations and mixed orders. A large class of such frames was identified to provide stable  signal reconstructions, and numerical experiments were conducted to test the new theory and algorithms.  (b) A super-frame based novel approach was developed for encoding-decoding protection signal recovering from erasure-corrupted data.  All such encoding/decoding frames were characterized and their construction algorithms were established. Numerical simulation shows that this can be achieved with very low computation cost and with higher accuracy. (c) Significant progresses were made on the phase-retrieval problem for structured signals by structured frames. (d) Several graduate and undergraduate students were supported to conduct research and two dissertation/thesis were resulted from this project.

The theory and new algorithms developed in this project have impact on advancing the research of frame theory and its applications to many problems within or outside the mathematical discipline. In particular, the newly established connections between representation theory and nonlinear reconstruction of signals many have significant impact on the research in the new direction of applications of group representation theory to signal/information processing.
